block.p: A Start-Up Recruits People To Donate DNA to Science A California start-up, DNA Sciences, is introducing a Web site that will recruit people to donate their DNA to help find genes that cause disease. The company hopes to get 50,000 to 100,000 people to contribute to its ''gene trust'' by appealing to their altruism.

The new effort reflects a big change taking place in genetics. Studies to link genes to disease are starting to be conducted on an unprecedented scale. While such studies promise to lead to big medical advances, the collection of genetic data on such a wide scale is also raising ethical and privacy issues. [Page A1.]

Pearson to Buy National Computer Pearson said that it was buying National Computer Systems, the largest scorer of student assessment tests in the United States, for $2.5 billion in cash. Several analysts said that while they supported efforts by Pearson's chief executive, Marjorie Scardino, to expand the company's role in educational publishing, they were concerned about the structure of the deal, which offers existing stockholders the right to buy some additional shares at a significant discount. Shares of Pearson fell 9 percent, to $:18.28, or $27.40. National Computer rose $13.75, to $71.875. [C11.]

Stocks Rise in Technology Rally Stock prices moved higher, led by technology issues. The Nasdaq composite index rose 103.99 points, or 2.8 percent, to 3,766.99, while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 10.81 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,521.98. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 10.94 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,430.83. [C12.]

Signs of Slowing in Manufacturing Manufacturing in the Midwest grew in July at the slowest pace in 18 months while more companies paid higher prices for raw materials, an industry survey showed. [C12.]

E-Tale Said to Be Near Break-Even A week into the horror writer Stephen King's closely watched experiment with self-publishing over the Internet, Mr. King said that he was about to break even. In a statement on his Web site, Mr. King estimated that readers downloaded 152,132 copies of the first chapter of ''The Plant'' in the first seven days. [C11.]

FPL Group Agrees to Buy Entergy FPL Group, the parent of Florida Power and Light, agreed to acquire Entergy for about $7 billion in stock in a deal that would create the nation's largest electric company. But the news sent shares of FPL lower, reducing the original value of the deal, on disappointment that FPL was not the takeover target. Shares of FPL fell $4.5625, to $48.25, while Entergy fell $3.1875, to $27.0625. [C2.]

Testimony in Auction Suit Delayed Justice Department antitrust prosecutors investigating Christie's and Sotheby's won a court order postponing the taking of testimony in a civil suit against the auction houses until at least Sept. 11. [C2.]

Deeper Tax Cuts Urged in Russia Changes in the Russian tax code seek to drag enormous portions of revenue out of hiding and onto company books by reducing the tax burden about 20 percent. But many businesses, which pay only a fraction of what they really owe, say that only deeper cuts and a fairer system will induce them to pay. [C4.]
Union Carbide Beats Expectations Union Carbide said that its second-quarter profits more than doubled, surpassing Wall Street estimates. [C5.]

Correction: August 2, 2000, Wednesday An entry in the Business Digest on Saturday about the purchase of Transamerica Leasing, which leases cargo containers, by a rival, Interpool, misstated the ownership of the companies. The Dutch insurer Aegon owns Transamerica Leasing; Interpool is independent.
